column5: These arrows represent country-to-country aid donations between 1973 and 2013
Each arrow represents the sum of donations from one country to another
column6: Larger and darker arrows indicate larger donations over the years
Notice that many arrows originate from Western Europe, Japan and the United States

column5: Net donors vs net receivers of aid
column6: Countries that donated more than they received are reds/oranges, whereas countries that received more than they donated are blues

column5: Countries in the middle of the color scale have smaller or near zero net flow of aid
column6: Smaller donations may be a result of the size of their country GDP or a result of roughly equal donation / receipt of aid over time.

Shaping the countries as circles highlights the donor/recipient trends even more: here we're scaling by magnitude of donations.

Notice that the US, Japan, Germany (DEU), and France are the largest donors.

Larger donors in the Middle East include Kuwait (KWT) Saudi Arabia (SAU), and the United Arab Emirates (ARE).

column5: Can you find the largest donation to a recipient country?
column6: Hover over a country to see statistics about their donation amounts. Can you find the largest donor-recipient donation sum?

column5: Who donates to whom? United States
column6: The United States has a broad portfolio of donations across the globe, with over … donors.

Hover over any donor country to see their donation "portfolio".

Arrows are sized relative to all net donations,
and shaded by net donation within the focus country, so darker arrows indicate the largest donations for a given country.

We can also scale by magnitude of aid received.

Indonesia (IDN), India (IND), China (CHN), and Brazil (BRA) have received the most aid: not surprising given their relatively large geographic sizes and populations.

column5: Where did the money come from
column6:
Hover over any recipient country to see all of their donor countries.

Arrows are sized relative to all net donations,
and shaded by net donation within the focus country, so darker arrows indicate the largest donations for a given country.
